title: Matt Messias
text:
Matthew David Messias (born 7 May 1964) is an English former <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Referee%20%28association%20football%29">referee</a>, who operated in <a href="the%20Football%20League">the Football League</a>, the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a>, and also for <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> and <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>. He was first based in <a href="York">York</a> during his time as an official, subsequently moving to <a href="Barnsley">Barnsley</a>, also in the county of <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a>. His other occupation was as a <a href="Physical%20education%20class%23Physical%20education">physical education</a> teacher.
Career.
He first took up refereeing in 1982, whilst still playing (for the <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a> county team, and for <a href="York%20St%20John%20University">St John's College</a> in York). His playing career ended after cartilage problems in 1984, and he became a PE Teacher at Filey School before taking up a post as head of PE in <a href="Thirsk">Thirsk</a>. At about this time, he started to get more involved in refereeing, first handling matches in the <a href="York%20Football%20League">York and District Saturday League</a>, then progressing to the <a href="Northern%20Counties%20East%20Football%20League">Northern Counties East League</a>.
After further promotions to the <a href="Football%20Combination">Football Combination</a> and the <a href="Football%20Conference">Football Conference</a>, he was appointed as an <a href="Assistant%20referee%20%28association%20football%29">assistant referee</a> on <a href="the%20Football%20League">the Football League</a> list in 1991, and in 1992, he advanced to the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> assistants' list. This was bettered in 1994 when he received the call from <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> to officiate for them as an assistant also.
In 1996, Messias became a Football League referee, and stepped up to the Premier League in season <a href="2000-01%20in%20English%20football">2000–01</a>, refereeing his first match on 16 December 2000 at <a href="Pride%20Park%20Stadium">Pride Park</a>, when <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a> defeated <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a> 1–0, thanks to a <a href="Malcolm%20Christie">Malcolm Christie</a> goal after 9 minutes. 
When <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a> played <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Spurs</a> in a Premier League match at <a href="Portman%20Road">Portman Road</a> on 12 January 2002, Messias failed to finish the game due to a calf injury, <a href="fourth%20official">fourth official</a> <a href="Rob%20Styles">Rob Styles</a> taking over from him. It was not serious, and he was able to referee an <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> match four days later.
In 2003, he was appointed to the list of <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> referees. Also in that year, he moved to <a href="Barnsley">Barnsley</a> from his previous home in <a href="York">York</a>. He had recently married, and the couple had recently had a baby together. Messias gained brief notoriety in August 2003 when, while refereeing a match between <a href="Newcastle%20United">Newcastle United</a> and <a href="Birmingham%20City">Birmingham City</a>, he accidentally struck <a href="Robbie%20Savage">Robbie Savage</a> in the face while signalling for a free kick.
On 24 May 2004, Messias was fourth official for <a href="Jeff%20Winter">Jeff Winter</a> at the <a href="FA%20Cup%20Final%202004">FA Cup Final</a>, when <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> beat <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a> by 3–0 at the <a href="Millennium%20Stadium">Millennium Stadium</a>, <a href="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>. He subsequently headed off to Germany for the <a href="2004%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship</a>, and first handled two group matches – <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> versus <a href="Belarus%20national%20football%20team">Belarus</a> on 27 May and <a href="Switzerland%20national%20football%20team">Switzerland</a> against <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a> on 30 May. Then, on 15 June 2004, he took charge of the competition <a href="semi-final">semi-final</a> between <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> and <a href="Serbia%20and%20Montenegro%20national%20football%20team">Serbia & Montenegro</a> at <a href="Oberhausen">Oberhausen</a>, which the latter country won 6–5 on <a href="Penalty%20shootout%20%28football%29">penalties</a> after a 0–0 draw following <a href="extra%20time">extra time</a>. He then went on to officiate from the middle twice in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in September 2004 – a first round tie between <a href="FK%20Dukla%20Bansk%C3%A1%20Bystrica">Banská Bystrica</a> and <a href="S.L.%20Benfica">Benfica</a>, which the <a href="Portugal">Portuguese</a> side won 3–0, and a group stage match as <a href="Feyenoord">Feyenoord</a> defeated <a href="FC%20Schalke%2004">Schalke 04</a> by 2 goals to 1.
2005 was a mixed year. In April Messias was suspended for 14 days "for less than proficiently applying the <a href="Laws%20of%20the%20Game%20%28association%20football%29">Laws of the Game</a>" according to the official <a href="The%20Football%20Association">Football Association</a> website. On 17 August 2005, he took control of a <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">2006 FIFA World Cup qualification</a> match between <a href="Republic%20of%20Macedonia%20national%20football%20team">FYR Macedonia</a> and <a href="Finland%20national%20football%20team">Finland</a> at <a href="Skopje%20City%20Stadium">Skopje City Stadium</a>, which the away side won 3–0. In September 2005, he also refereed a UEFA Cup first round tie between <a href="F.C.%20Copenhagen">F.C. Copenhagen</a> and <a href="Hamburger%20SV">SV Hamburg</a>. In November 2005, Messias was rated fourth best referee in England by UEFA. 
On 19 January 2006, the <a href="Professional%20Game%20Match%20Officials%20Limited">Professional Game Match Officials Limited</a> announced that by mutual consent Messias would retire as a <a href="Select%20Group%20referee">Select Group referee</a> as of 1 February 2006. As it turned out, by the time of the announcement, he had already chosen his last game to referee in a top class competition, this being the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> third round tie between <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> and <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a> at <a href="the%20Hawthorns">the Hawthorns</a> on 7 January 2006, which finished 1–1, courtesy of two penalties converted in the last eight minutes.
In April 2006, it was reported that Messias had openly admitted to being persuaded by players to "let them get on with it" during the match between <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolves</a> and Millwall at <a href="Molineux%20stadium">Molineux</a> on 19 April 2003. <a href="Keith%20Hackett">Keith Hackett</a>, the Premier League referees' chief, suggested that may have been the reason he retired and that he was not disbelieving what he has said "sometimes when you are away from the game things can get exaggerated." Messias explained that professional referees are under a lot of pressure and you "learn to deal with it- to control the controllables."
Life after football.
He ran a business, Matt Messias Consultancy Limited, offering help in coping with stressful occupations similar to that of an active professional football referee. He also appears as a guest speaker at sporting events. He was an adviser to the main Barnsley Football Club, and had become refereeing mentor to <a href="Ryan%20Newman%20%28referee%29">Ryan Newman</a> from Barnsley, who had recently become a <a href="Conference%20North">Conference North</a> league referee.
He visited schools to pass on the benefit of his experience. On 25 September 2007, he attended the Leicestershire & Rutland PE & Sport Conference 2007, held at <a href="Loughborough%20University">Loughborough University</a>, where he delivered <a href="keynote%20address">keynote address</a>es intended to 'Include, Improve and Inspire'. Messias and his family migrated to <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> on 7 October 2008. Messias continued his teaching career at <a href="Macleans%20College">Macleans College</a> <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>, where he taught physical education (PE) and coached the 1st XI Girls Football team until early 2011. He then worked as a deputy principal at <a href="Howick%20College">Howick College</a>. In July 2014 he left New Zealand to return to the UK to take up a position as foundation principal of the Atrium Studio School in Devon.
In September 2018, d back up to York with his wife and two sons. He started supply teaching for two days a week and works on his personal business to help people with mental health issues three days a week. He hopes to launch his business in January 2019.
